thread.title: You Can Now Do CPR to More Than Just Disco Music
thread.title_full: You Can Now Do CPR to More Than Just Disco Music

author: Beth Skwarecki on Vitals, shared by Beth Skwarecki to Lifehacker
title: You Can Now Do CPR to More Than Just Disco Music
text:
Photo via VisualHunt . 
If you’re trying to remember how to do CPR, but the guideline song Stayin’ Alive just doesn’t stick in your head, New York Presbyterian Hospital has a 40-song playlist you can browse instead. All of the songs are a CPR-friendly 100+ beats per minute. Songs to do CPR to, a playlist on Spotify Songs to do CPR to, a playlist on Spotify Songs to do CPR to, a playlist on Spotify All of these songs are 100 BPM – the right beat to perform CPR. Pick one to remember in case you… Read more Read more 
The idea behind picking a song is to have something you can sing in your head while delivering chest compressions. ( Don’t bother stopping to give breaths , unless you’ve been trained otherwise; “hands only” CPR is effective.) A pace of 100 per minute is the minimum, and cheery CPR instructors have often recommended Stayin’ Alive or I Will Survive as good tunes to keep in mind. More cynical folks prefer Another One Bites the Dust. (CPR boosts survival rates, but the statistics are still grim.) All the First Aid Stuff That's Changed Since You First Learned It All the First Aid Stuff That's Changed Since You First Learned It All the First Aid Stuff That's Changed Since You… When was the last time you took a first aid class? The ‘80s? ‘90s? Like everything in the medical… Read more Read more 
Not everybody grew up on disco, so you’ll want a familiar song in your head when the moment comes. In Japan, Ob-La-Di Ob-La-Da is better known . And New York Presbyterian’s playlist has plenty more choices: Missy Elliott’s Work It, ABBA’s Dancing Queen, Michael Jackson’s Man in the Mirror, or (if you really must) Train’s Soul Sister. Advertisement Advertisement 
After you browse the playlist, though, make sure to brush up on how to actually do CPR. In a study brilliantly titled Achy Breaky Makey Wakey Heart? A Randomized Crossover Trial of Musical Prompts , researchers found that no matter what song volunteers used, most still didn’t press hard enough. Taking a class with a realistic model will help you understand how to position your hands and how hard to push—it’s harder than you think. You can find CPR classes through the American Heart Association , the American Red Cross , or your local hospital or fire station.
